guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

meta_title: The Bible Contains Errors – Rival Nations
title: The Bible Contains Errors. But that's okay.

body: Inerrancy started with Sola Scriptural because the Catholic Church had been taking so many liberties with scripture for so long that the bible was the only uncorrupted thing the Reformers could refer to.
body_html: Inerrancy started with Sola Scriptural because the Catholic Church had been taking so many liberties with scripture for so long that the bible was the only uncorrupted thing the Reformers could refer to.

body: Unfortunately those liberties included, in the early days, editing scripture itself, meaning even it is corrupt. Though even without them other groups still corrupted it in minor ways, and even without that there would still be honest mistakes, and even without *that* the original author could've simply been wrong. The old testament is similar, being corrupted primarily by the levitical priesthood and the bloodthirsty religious cult that became dominant in Israel and Judah, and scribes during the Babylonian exile.
body_html: Unfortunately those liberties included, in the early days, editing scripture itself, meaning even it is corrupt. Though even without them other groups still corrupted it in minor ways, and even without that there would still be honest mistakes, and even without that the original author could've simply been wrong. The old testament is similar, being corrupted primarily by the levitical priesthood and the bloodthirsty religious cult that became dominant in Israel and Judah, and scribes during the Babylonian exile.

body: If it contains no errors, then its warning of itself being corrupted by dishonest scribes cannot be an error: "How can you say, 'we are wise, and the law of YHWH is with us'? Look, in reality the lying pen of scribes wrote to deceive!" (Jeremiah 8:8).
body_html: If it contains no errors, then its warning of itself being corrupted by dishonest scribes cannot be an error: "How can you say, 'we are wise, and the law of YHWH is with us'? Look, in reality the lying pen of scribes wrote to deceive!" (Jeremiah 8:8).

post.meta_title: The Bible Contains Errors – Rival Nations
post.title: The Bible Contains Errors. But that's okay.

body:
Meh is a moot point. Any religion is a matter of belief. It's like that with all philosophy. The saving grace of all religions is that they give you hope for an after life. Really all religions are driven by the fear of death.

You can quote Romans with the whole "for I have shown myself to those who have not heard" which justifies god as being accepting of everyone, but really there is no god to accept anyone.

The simplest argument is this. If you believe in God you either can't believe in evolution or you have to believe that all living things have souls.

If you don't believe in evolution, cool. That's a bold statement Cotton.

If you do, does an amoeba have a soul? How about a tree?

The second bit is, OK, let's say they're is a god. There was no big bang. It was a snap of the fingers. Adam and Eve are figurative. Evolution happened but without the divine forces of God aside from the initial spark. God wouldn't care.

 If you read the early representations of Jesus within 200 years of him dying, no one knew what what going on. You had Jesus was God. Jesus was a prophet. Jesus was a weird hybrid. There were a grip of random beliefs. It wasn't until the council of Nicaea in the mid 300s that people when decided what the Bible should be. Look up the gospel of Bartholomew. There were things going between Christian churches that the higher-ups decided to leave our because it didn't serve their purpose. Look into the actual history of the tithing scriptures. 

Christianity was created by man. All that however doesn't negate is value. It's a code of ethics. It's a rule book for life. And to be honest the new testament is a pretty good take on things. Jesus said (maybe) don't be a dick. Don't corrupt yourself. Help people. These are things you should listen to.

Errors or not. Real or not. Who cares. Do what Jesus said and don't be a dick.

You can quote Romans with the whole "for I have shown myself to those who have not heard" which justifies god as being accepting of everyone, but really there is no god to accept anyone.

The simplest argument is this. If you believe in God you either can't believe in evolution or you have to believe that all living things have souls.

If you don't believe in evolution, cool. That's a bold statement Cotton.

If you do, does an amoeba have a soul? How about a tree?

The second bit is, OK, let's say they're is a god. There was no big bang. It was a snap of the fingers. Adam and Eve are figurative. Evolution happened but without the divine forces of God aside from the initial spark. God wouldn't care.

If you read the early representations of Jesus within 200 years of him dying, no one knew what what going on. You had Jesus was God. Jesus was a prophet. Jesus was a weird hybrid. There were a grip of random beliefs. It wasn't until the council of Nicaea in the mid 300s that people when decided what the Bible should be. Look up the gospel of Bartholomew. There were things going between Christian churches that the higher-ups decided to leave our because it didn't serve their purpose. Look into the actual history of the tithing scriptures.

Christianity was created by man. All that however doesn't negate is value. It's a code of ethics. It's a rule book for life. And to be honest the new testament is a pretty good take on things. Jesus said (maybe) don't be a dick. Don't corrupt yourself. Help people. These are things you should listen to.

Errors or not. Real or not. Who cares. Do what Jesus said and don't be a dick.

body:
It is corrupted by miriads of bad translations which even 20 years was degenderizing it.

For English, If you look at the Septuagint and for the New Testament only orthodox translations from the original Greek all your "Errors" disappear.
body_html:
It is corrupted by miriads of bad translations which even 20 years was degenderizing it.

For English, If you look at the Septuagint and for the New Testament only orthodox translations from the original Greek all your "Errors" disappear.

post.meta_title: The Bible Contains Errors – Rival Nations
post.title: The Bible Contains Errors. But that's okay.

body:
> The Bible not only contains the word of God; it is the word of God. The primary author is the Holy Ghost, or, as it is commonly expressed, the human authors wrote under the influence of Divine inspiration. It was declared by the Vatican Council (Sess. III, c. ii) that the sacred and canonical character of Scripture would not be sufficiently explained by saying that the books were composed by human diligence and then approved by the Church, or that they contained revelation without error. They are sacred and canonical "because, having been written by inspiration of the Holy Ghost, that have God for their author, and as such have been handed down to the Church". The inerrancy of the Bible follows as a consequence of this Divine authorship. Wherever the sacred writer makes a statement as his own, that statement is the word of God and infallibly true, whatever be the subject-matter of the statement. https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02543a.htm

To say the Bible is erroneous would then it seems be some kind of error or heresy I think from the Catholic viewpoint

so why are there discrepencies?

> As a literature, our sacred books have been transcribed during many centuries by all manner of copyists to the ignorance and carelessness of many of whom they still bear witness in the shape of numerous textual errors, which, however, but seldom interfere seriously with the primitive reading of any important dogmatic or moral passage of Holy Writ.

I'd have to look up what inerrancy means, perhaps it is in the moral sense, not that we need to know if 7 or 8 is the correct number in a certain instance, but of a number nearby that estimate, and where the meaning of the passage is not affected by disagreements over the exact number. Or perhaps there are no actual errors in this way, I would have to research more what is meant.
body_html:
The Bible not only contains the word of God; it is the word of God. The primary author is the Holy Ghost, or, as it is commonly expressed, the human authors wrote under the influence of Divine inspiration. It was declared by the Vatican Council (Sess. III, c. ii) that the sacred and canonical character of Scripture would not be sufficiently explained by saying that the books were composed by human diligence and then approved by the Church, or that they contained revelation without error. They are sacred and canonical "because, having been written by inspiration of the Holy Ghost, that have God for their author, and as such have been handed down to the Church". The inerrancy of the Bible follows as a consequence of this Divine authorship. Wherever the sacred writer makes a statement as his own, that statement is the word of God and infallibly true, whatever be the subject-matter of the statement. https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02543a.htm

To say the Bible is erroneous would then it seems be some kind of error or heresy I think from the Catholic viewpoint

so why are there discrepencies?

As a literature, our sacred books have been transcribed during many centuries by all manner of copyists to the ignorance and carelessness of many of whom they still bear witness in the shape of numerous textual errors, which, however, but seldom interfere seriously with the primitive reading of any important dogmatic or moral passage of Holy Writ.

I'd have to look up what inerrancy means, perhaps it is in the moral sense, not that we need to know if 7 or 8 is the correct number in a certain instance, but of a number nearby that estimate, and where the meaning of the passage is not affected by disagreements over the exact number. Or perhaps there are no actual errors in this way, I would have to research more what is meant.

body: There are lots of errors and deliberate changes, especially in the earliest days of transmission. We have absolutely no evidence of God ever calling the books included in the bible inerrant, in fact the opposite is implied in many cases, especially Jeremiah chapters 7-11. This matches the evidence very well *and* resolves countless theological problems and contradictions. Even the original autographs, for the most part, were not written by people who thought their work would even survive beyond their lifetime, let alone end up as "inerrant scripture". The Pauline epistles, for example, almost indisputably the most popular part of the bible, were never intended for anyone except specific clusters of early believers, and much of it is subjective opinion of the author, and on top of that our current text is severely damaged by the redactors.
body_html: There are lots of errors and deliberate changes, especially in the earliest days of transmission. We have absolutely no evidence of God ever calling the books included in the bible inerrant, in fact the opposite is implied in many cases, especially Jeremiah chapters 7-11. This matches the evidence very well and resolves countless theological problems and contradictions. Even the original autographs, for the most part, were not written by people who thought their work would even survive beyond their lifetime, let alone end up as "inerrant scripture". The Pauline epistles, for example, almost indisputably the most popular part of the bible, were never intended for anyone except specific clusters of early believers, and much of it is subjective opinion of the author, and on top of that our current text is severely damaged by the redactors.

parent.body:
> The Bible not only contains the word of God; it is the word of God. The primary author is the Holy Ghost, or, as it is commonly expressed, the human authors wrote under the influence of Divine inspiration. It was declared by the Vatican Council (Sess. III, c. ii) that the sacred and canonical character of Scripture would not be sufficiently explained by saying that the books were composed by human diligence and then approved by the Church, or that they contained revelation without error. They are sacred and canonical "because, having been written by inspiration of the Holy Ghost, that have God for their author, and as such have been handed down to the Church". The inerrancy of the Bible follows as a consequence of this Divine authorship. Wherever the sacred writer makes a statement as his own, that statement is the word of God and infallibly true, whatever be the subject-matter of the statement. https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02543a.htm

To say the Bible is erroneous would then it seems be some kind of error or heresy I think from the Catholic viewpoint

so why are there discrepencies?

> As a literature, our sacred books have been transcribed during many centuries by all manner of copyists to the ignorance and carelessness of many of whom they still bear witness in the shape of numerous textual errors, which, however, but seldom interfere seriously with the primitive reading of any important dogmatic or moral passage of Holy Writ.

I'd have to look up what inerrancy means, perhaps it is in the moral sense, not that we need to know if 7 or 8 is the correct number in a certain instance, but of a number nearby that estimate, and where the meaning of the passage is not affected by disagreements over the exact number. Or perhaps there are no actual errors in this way, I would have to research more what is meant.
parent.body_html:
The Bible not only contains the word of God; it is the word of God. The primary author is the Holy Ghost, or, as it is commonly expressed, the human authors wrote under the influence of Divine inspiration. It was declared by the Vatican Council (Sess. III, c. ii) that the sacred and canonical character of Scripture would not be sufficiently explained by saying that the books were composed by human diligence and then approved by the Church, or that they contained revelation without error. They are sacred and canonical "because, having been written by inspiration of the Holy Ghost, that have God for their author, and as such have been handed down to the Church". The inerrancy of the Bible follows as a consequence of this Divine authorship. Wherever the sacred writer makes a statement as his own, that statement is the word of God and infallibly true, whatever be the subject-matter of the statement. https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02543a.htm

To say the Bible is erroneous would then it seems be some kind of error or heresy I think from the Catholic viewpoint

so why are there discrepencies?

As a literature, our sacred books have been transcribed during many centuries by all manner of copyists to the ignorance and carelessness of many of whom they still bear witness in the shape of numerous textual errors, which, however, but seldom interfere seriously with the primitive reading of any important dogmatic or moral passage of Holy Writ.

I'd have to look up what inerrancy means, perhaps it is in the moral sense, not that we need to know if 7 or 8 is the correct number in a certain instance, but of a number nearby that estimate, and where the meaning of the passage is not affected by disagreements over the exact number. Or perhaps there are no actual errors in this way, I would have to research more what is meant.
